item.title: Application DR architecture keeping same IP
item.description: DR steady state Protected site: On-Prem Recovery site: AVS DR Platform: VMware Site Recovery Protected VMs: 3 On-Prem VMs replicated in SRM Port Group (PG) Placeholder VMs: 3 AVS placeholder VMs created on recovery site and kept up to date DR Test DR test platform: Site Recovery Manager (SRM) DR test network: Isolated Segment in AVS DR Migration DR migration platform: Site Recovery Manager (SRM) Protected VMs: 3 On-Prem VMs will be shutdown Recovery VMs: 3 AVS VMs will be powered on Recovery VM network: Layer 2 extended network Network extension platform: HCX DR Event Protected Site: no longer available Recovery Site: AVS Recovery VMs: all VMs come up on AVS Recovery VM network: Layer 3 segment Recovery network platform: NSX-t (part of AVS)

item.title: AVS NSXT NVA Architectures
item.description: Customer can deploy self-managed NVAs like FireWall, Loadbalancer, etc, inside of AVS Private Cloud. From NSX-T’s point of view it is just another Virtual Machine (VM). Here, NVA has to be in routed path, where, it acts as network gateway for the layer 3 segment. From scale point of view, ESXi supports 10 network interfaces per VM. 1 interface can be used for uplink 1 for management 8 segments are then left to create security zones.

item.title: AVS Reservation
item.description: Azure VMware Solution (AVS) Host Reservation Introduction AVS host by default are created using on-demand billing rates but if Reserved Instance (RI) for AVS host is purchased then customer can reduce the overall billing commitment. Azure AVS Reserved Instance Documentation covers 2 routes: Buy Reserved Instances for an Enterprise Agreement (EA) subscription Buy Reserved Instances for a Cloud Solution Provider (CSP) subscription Requirements AVS Subscription value AVS Region Reservation duration: 1 year or 3 years Payment duration: upfront or monthly Number of hosts to reserve User purchasing the reservation should have at least one of these roles: 1.
